exchanges.name: PancakeSwap
exchanges.query_example: Query all pairs with GraphQL: { pairs(first: 1000) { id token0 { symbol } token1 { symbol } reserve0 reserve1 } }
exchanges.notes: Can query all pairs in one GraphQL request. Use pagination (first/skip) for large datasets. REST API may have /pairs endpoint but Subgraph is recommended.

exchanges.name: Uniswap
exchanges.query_example: Query all pairs: { pairs(first: 1000) { id token0 { symbol } token1 { symbol } reserve0 reserve1 } }
exchanges.notes: Subgraph allows querying all pairs in one request. Also has REST Routing API but it's for quotes, not bulk data.

exchanges.name: Sushi

exchanges.notes: Uses The Graph Subgraph - can query all pairs in one GraphQL request.

notes.subgraph_approach: For Subgraph-based DEX, use GraphQL queries with pagination (first/skip parameters) to get all pairs in batches. Example: first: 1000, skip: 0, then skip: 1000, etc.
notes.rest_approach: For REST APIs, look for endpoints like /pools, /markets, /pairs, /tickers that return all available pairs. Some may require pagination.
notes.recommendation: For monitoring, consider: 1) Using Subgraph for bulk data (most efficient), 2) Caching results, 3) Using WebSocket where available for real-time updates, 4) Implementing rate limiting to respect API limits
